section.title: Working with the DB Object tree
section.para: The DB Object Tree offers a similar functionality as the but can be displayed alongside the SQL editor tabs. The DB Object tree offers a subset of the features the DbExplorer offers.
The DB Object tree always uses a separate connection.

section.title: Filtering the elements in the tree
Dropping elements into the SQL editor
section.para:
In general, dropping an element into the editor, will insert the element's name into the editor. There are however two exceptions to this rule:
dropping the "Columns" node of the tree, will insert a comma separated list of all columns dropping a table into a SELECT statement's column list will insert a comma separated list of all columns dropping a table into a position where not current SQL statement is located, a SELECT statement for the table will be inserted

section.title: Displaying a table's data
section.para: To display the data of a table, just drag the table node from the DB Object Tree to the result panel of the current SQL editor. &wb-productname; will then generate an approriate SELECT statement for the table and execute it immediately.
